Comment:
Hi everyone!

Here is a razor sharp game against Expert Nyctalop.  Nyctalop has kindly commented on my previous annotations so I thought I would try my luck against him.  I tried to attack but it was rebuffed big time.  The story starts with a Scilian Defense. 1. e4  c5.
4. Nxd4 - fairly standard play so far.
4. Nxd4 - fairly standard play so far.
4. Nxd4 - fairly standard play so far.
4. Nxd4 - fairly standard play so far.
4. Nxd4 - fairly standard play so far.
4. Nxd4 - fairly standard play so far.

5. Nc3 - it is considered bad play to play Nxc6 as bxc6 allows black to build up a pawn centre.  Mind you I did do this exchange in an OTB friendly against a player with an 1824 rating way back in 1999 and went on to win in spectacular fashion.  Sadly I did not notate that game but it is in my memory - my rating was 1240!  Still, I decided not to chance it here and play Nc3 - a developing move which defends the pawn on e4.

5. Nc3 - it is considered bad play to play Nxc6 as bxc6 allows black to build up a pawn centre.  Mind you I did do this exchange in an OTB friendly against a player with an 1824 rating way back in 1999 and went on to win in spectacular fashion.  Sadly I did not notate that game but it is in my memory - my rating was 1240!  Still, I decided not to chance it here and play Nc3 - a developing move which defends the pawn on e4.
6. Ndb5 - I go into the Sveshnikov Variation.  This variation is razor sharp as you will soon see.

14. ...... Bg7 - if Nxd5 then Bxf5.  This bishop will be very strong on that diagonal, especially when black plays b4 at a convenient moment.

15. Qh5 - Glenda goes to h5 intending to spearhead a mating attack if black castles short.  The move also piles up on the f5 pawn.
15. ...... e4 - crosses my attack on f5 now Fou Leblanc must retreat.  He chooses c2 hitting out indirectly at h7.
17. ...... Qc8 - very strong, putting pressure on c3.

19. ..... b4 - at last black plays that dreaded b4.  I take on e4 - it is the last move before we enter open play.

21. exf5 - this move looks strong but black has an answer.
22. ..... Ng6 - defends against all threats.  I now decided to regain my piece.  Maybe I should have traded rooks, but I leave it to you the Inquest Jury to decide!

26. ..... Ne5 - threatening no doubt Nd3.

28. ..... Rc8 - I decided to wave the white flag here as I have no defense to Qc1.  There would follow something like this Variation A

29. h3 Qc1 
30. Qxc1 Rxc1 
31. Rxc1 bxc1=Q+ 

Or just a little bit worse ......

Variation B

29. Qb1 Qc1 
30. Rxc1 Rxc1+ 
31. Qxc1 bxc1=Q+ 
32. Bd1 Qxd1#

Ending up a rook to the bad in Variation A.

So well played there nyctalop.
